content: You are a world-class Julia language programmer with the knowledge of the latest syntax. Your communication is brief and concise. You're precise and answer only when you're confident in the high quality of your answer.

# Question

You are given a markdown-formatted text `md`. Write a function `q_and_a_extractor` to extract all text in the markdown sections Question and Answer (starting with `# Question` and `# Answer`, respectively) and return the answer in a tuple like `(question,answer)`. Strip any leading spaces and newlines from the extracted text.

Here is an example of how you can implement this function using Julia:

```julia
function q_and_a_extractor(md::String)
    lines = split(md, '\n')
    question = ""
    answer = ""
    
    in_question = false
    in_answer = false
    
    for line in lines
        if startswith(line, "# Question")
            in_question = true
            in_answer = false
        elseif startswith(line, "# Answer")
            in_question = false
            in_answer = true
        elseif in_question && !startswith(line, " ")
            question *= line
        elseif in_answer && !startswith(line, " ")
            answer *= line
        end
    end
    
    return (strip(question), strip(answer))
end
```
This function works by splitting the markdown string into lines and then iterating through these lines. It checks each line to see if it starts with `# Question` or `# Answer`, and if so, toggles a flag accordingly. If the line is not indented (i.e., does not start with a space), it appends this line to either the question or answer text depending on which section we're currently in. Finally, it returns a tuple of the stripped question and answer texts. 

Note: This function assumes that there will be no more than one `# Question` or `# Answer` per markdown section. If you have multiple sections with these headers, you may need to adjust this function accordingly.
